topics.title: Cold open: speed and quality aren’t a trade-off
topics.summary: Nan argues the perceived speed-vs-quality trade-off is a misconception: true speed comes from competence, enabling more iterations and better outcomes. He frames fast, expert execution as a predictor of high-quality output.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Nan Yu and tees up key topics: Linear’s product system, customer empathy, speed/quality, and career advice. He positions Linear as a uniquely beloved B2B SaaS product and previews what listeners will learn.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Sinch (customer communications APIs and RCS) and Paragon (integration infrastructure for B2B SaaS, RAG/agents, and workflow integrations).

topics.title: Why people want to switch from Jira
topics.summary: Lenny shares survey results showing Linear is the #1 tool people wish they could switch to (from Jira), citing praise for simplicity, design, and speed. Nan explains Linear’s origin story: removing workflow “speed bumps” that make builders hate daily work.

topics.title: Operationalizing fast, high-quality product iteration
topics.summary: Nan defines “speed” as having a workable prototype by ~10% of the time budget to test key hypotheses early. He attributes this to strong talent, intentional rough V1s, and focusing on learning rather than perfection.

topics.title: Progressive rollout: internal, beta groups, then GA
topics.summary: Nan describes Linear’s expanding circles of release: internal use first, then early-access customers, then broader betas, and finally GA. Engagement (or lack of it) becomes a key signal for whether they hit the mark.

topics.title: Avoiding bloat by saying no to reporting-driven customization
topics.summary: Nan explains Linear’s hard line: reject customization requests that help middle-manager reporting at the expense of IC workflows. He argues these features degrade data quality anyway because ICs disengage or fill fields randomly.

topics.title: Enterprise growth without compromising the product
topics.summary: They discuss the fear of turning down big deals and how Linear navigates enterprise needs (e.g., SAML/SCIM) while resisting workflow-harming asks. Nan notes enterprise growth is strong as Linear becomes a credible “enterprise brand” for teams that want to move like startups.

topics.title: How Linear debates features: real people, real workflows
topics.summary: Nan describes harder product debates: extend existing primitives vs add new services, grounded in concrete, named users and their workflows. He warns against elegant solutions that don’t match messy reality and explains how they evaluate feedback (wrong mental model vs many disparate use cases).

topics.title: Case study: Customer Requests instead of custom fields
topics.summary: Nan explains how repeated “custom fields” requests often masked a customer-tracking need for B2B teams. Linear built Customer Requests to connect to support/CRM sources and auto-tag issues by customer, improving reporting without burdening ICs.

topics.title: Customer calls: dig for emotions to find real problems
topics.summary: Nan shares his approach to discovery: keep probing until he can “feel bad” the way the customer feels, uncovering the emotional driver behind requests. Example: date commitments causing cross-team conflict led Linear to support flexible date granularity (month/quarter/half-year).

topics.title: Emotional hooks and schlep blindness in competitive markets
topics.summary: Nan argues that in crowded categories, goal-based JTBD is table stakes; differentiation comes from identifying recurring “bad feelings” and removing them. He references “schlep blindness” and gives an example of hating Mondays due to manual reporting work.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Wix Studio, highlighting tools for agencies and marketers: dynamic pages, integrations, A/B testing, analytics, social management, and extensibility.

topics.title: Recap and nuance: incentives, mental models, and backlog shaping
topics.summary: Lenny summarizes Linear’s principles; Nan adds nuance: focus on incentive misalignments between user groups, not just “the user.” Nan then explains how Linear manages a backlog of 20–30 opportunities by continuously updating shared analyses to refine the team’s customer mental model.

topics.title: Example opportunity: capacity planning and scoping the solution
topics.summary: Nan describes capacity planning as an unsolved, spreadsheet-driven pain point and explains Linear is still building conviction on what portion of the problem they should tackle. The goal is a strong starting point using existing Linear data, not solving the entire domain at once.
